bill.title: Reaffirming the leadership of the United States in promoting the safety, health, and well-being of refugees and displaced persons.

item.name: War crimes, genocide, crimes against humanity

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.
Sponsor introductory remarks on measure. (CR H4985)

item.title: Reaffirming the leadership of the United States in promoting the safety, health, and well-being of refugees and displaced persons.
Reaffirming the leadership of the United States in promoting the safety, health, and well-being of refugees and displaced persons.

item.name: Introduced in House
item.text:
Reaffirms: (1) the bipartisan commitment of the United States to promote the safety, health, and well-being of refugees; and (2) the goals of World Refugee Day.

Recognizes those who have risked their lives to provide life-saving assistance and to help protect people displaced by conflict.

Calls upon the U.S. government to:

  • uphold its international leadership role in responding to displacement crises with humanitarian assistance for, and protection of, the most vulnerable populations;
  • work in partnership with the international community to find solutions to existing conflicts and to prevent new conflicts;
  • continue to support the efforts of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and to advance the work of nongovernmental organizations to protect refugees regardless of their country of origin or religious beliefs; and
  • continue to mitigate, through humanitarian and development support, the burden placed on frontline refugee host countries that absorb the majority of the world's refugees.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Foreign Affairs.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
